Graphical abstract An electrochemical activation strategy with selective etching guides the reconstruction process of a hybrid cobalt-molybdenum oxide in a favorable direction to construct a highly active and dynamically stable amorphous-crystalline heterojunction for OER. Surface reconstruction yields real active species in electrochemical oxygen evolution reaction (OER) conditions; however, rationally regulating reconstruction in a targeted manner for constructing highly active OER electrocatalysts remains a formidable challenge. Here, an electrochemical activation strategy with selective etching was utilized to guide the reconstruction process of a hybrid cobalt-molybdenum oxide (CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC) in a favorable direction to improve the OER performance. Both in-situ Raman and multiple ex-situ characterization tools demonstrate that controlled surface reconstruction can be easily achieved through Mo etching, with the formation of a dynamically stable amorphous-crystalline heterostructure. Theoretical calculations together with experimental results reveal that the synergistic effects between amorphous CoOOH and crystalline Co3O4 are crucial in enhancing the catalytic performance. Consequently, the reconstructed CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC exhibits a low overpotential of 250 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH, and more importantly it can be practiced in electrolytic water splitting and rechargeable zinc-air batteries devices, achieving ultra-long stability for over 500 and 1200 h, respectively. This work provides a promising route for the construction of high-performance electrocatalysts. Keywords Electrocatalyst Oxygen evolution reaction Surface reconstruction Selective etching Amorphous-crystalline heterostructures 1 Introduction The electrochemical oxygen evolution reaction (OER) plays a vital role in next-generation energy production technologies, such as electrolytic water splitting, CO2 reduction, and rechargeable metal-air batteries [1–3]. However, the OER on the anode involves a complex four-electron process and suffers from intrinsically sluggish kinetics, which greatly impairs the efficiency of these electrochemical systems [4–6]. The state-of-the-art noble metal-based catalysts, Ir and Ru-based oxides electrocatalysts, are too expensive and scarce for their large-scale applications [7,8]. To this end, plenty of nonprecious metal-based materials, such as transition metal oxides [9], hydroxides [10], chalcogenides [11], and phosphates [12], have been developed as efficient catalysts for alkaline OER. Nevertheless, with increasing attention to the dynamic evolution of electrocatalysts during electrocatalysis, more and more operando studies have recently greatly challenged the structure-activity relationships based on the structural models of the original materials before the electrochemical reactions [13–16]. Under OER conditions, many transition metal-based materials are known to undergo surface reconstruction to in-situ form metal oxyhydroxide species that are widely recognized as the real catalytic active species for OER and determine the performance of electrocatalysts [13,14,17]. A typical example happens in the Co-based electrocatalysts, where the OER activity of CoOOH reconstructed from CoS2 shows remarkable enhancement compared to its pure counterpart [17]. While it may seem intuitive that increasing the surface reconstruction level would enhance OER activity by exposing more active sites, the resulting surface structures often exhibit low crystallinity or even amorphous nature, resulting in low electrical conductivity and restricted charge transfer kinetics [18,19]. Additionally, with the growth of amorphous surfaces, the material may collapse and dissolve into the electrolyte, leading to poor operational stability [13,14,20]. Therefore, how to promote and regulate the reconstruction towards desired configurations that can optimize the electrocatalytic performance is a formidable challenge, and resolving this challenge is critical for a thorough understanding of reconstruction and the design of high-efficiency OER electrocatalysts. Considering the inherent amorphous nature of the in-situ formed active metal oxyhydroxides, a viable solution lies in the construction of amorphous-crystalline heterostructures through the combination of OER-stable crystalline phases and these amorphous metal oxyhydroxides. This approach offers several advantages. (1) The stable crystalline phases possess favorable electronic transfer and tightly arranged structures with remarkable corrosion resistance [21,22]. (2) The amorphous metal oxyhydroxides feature a high oxidation state of the metal sites and a spatial disorder in their structures, providing a wealth of active sites for OER [23,24]. (3) The interfaces between the amorphous and crystalline phases can modulate the electron densities of the interfacial sites, thus optimizing the adsorption and desorption of oxygen-containing intermediates [21,23]. In the context of transition metal compounds, it appears that only thermodynamically stable oxides can maintain their crystalline phase during alkaline OER [13,14,25]. For instance, Co3O4 is a renowned spinel oxide, consisting of tetrahedral and octahedral sites which are occupied by Co(II) and Co(III) ions, repetitively. To date, Co3O4 materials have been explored in noteworthy applications like electrochemical energy conversion, storage, and catalysis due to their good conductivity, high thermal and mechanical stability [26,27]. Recently, it was reported that Co3O4 has been found to retain its crystalline structure throughout the electrochemical reactions, ensuring a stable OER operation [20,28]. Its stability can be attributed to the similar *OH adsorption capacity of the Co octahedron and Co tetrahedron sites within Co3O4, which facilitates fast deprotonation without the accumulation of intermediates [29,30]. However, the limited availability of the active site of spinel Co3O4 limits the efficiency of electrochemical OER. Although a huge amount of research work has been performed on Co3O4 materials with different exposed crystal surfaces [31], diverse dopants [32], and various microstructures [33], there is still an enormous challenge to fabricate Co3O4-based materials with enhanced OER. For example, Zhang et al. [32] reported that vulcanized Co3O4 nanocubes deliver an overpotential of 314 mV at 10 mA cm−2 with a small Tafel slope of 67.4 mV dec−1 in 1 M KOH. Unlike spinel Co3O4, several cobalt-based composite oxides, CoCr2O4 [34] and CoMoO4 [35,36], undergo structural reconstruction and become amorphous after OER. In particular, CoMoO4 materials exhibit a well-documented reconstruction process, where Co species rapidly reconstruct into active amorphous CoOOH at oxidation potentials due to the leaching of MoO4 2− [36]. For instance, Zhang et al. [37] demonstrated that Mo-doped cobalt oxyhydroxide (Mo1-CoOOH) generated from structural evolution occurring on the surface of CoMo1O4@CP exhibits a low overpotential of 274 mV at 10 mA cm−2 with a small Tafel slope of 66 mV dec−1 in 1 M KOH. Building on these findings, it is conceivable that if in-situ constructing amorphous-crystalline heterostructures through the rational reconstruction of hybrid oxides contain both OER-susceptible and OER-stable components, it may be possible to achieve exceptional activity and stability simultaneously for OER. Herein, unlike the conventional synthesis of amorphous-crystalline heterostructures in material systems [38–40], an electrochemical activation strategy with selective etching is implemented to a hybrid cobalt-molybdenum oxide (CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC) for the formation of dynamically stable amorphous-crystalline heterostructures to improve OER performance. In-situ Raman and multiple ex-situ techniques capture the surface reconstruction process of CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC, in which the CoMoO4 component undergoes rapid phase transformation into active amorphous CoOOH due to Mo etching, while the Co3O4 component dynamically maintains its crystalline structure during OER. Both theoretical calculations and experimental results demonstrate that the heterostructures with synergistic effects on the one hand can synergistically strengthen the conductivity of the catalyst and accelerate the charge transfer, and on the other hand modulate the 3d orbitals of Co sites and optimize the adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates on Co sites, thus facilitating the OER kinetics. As a result, the resulting catalyst exhibits a low overpotential of 250 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH. More importantly, this catalyst is practiced in electrolytic water splitting and rechargeable zinc-air batteries, achieving ultra-long stability for over 500 and 1200 h, respectively. This work provides a novel perspective for the design of highly efficient non-precious metal-based OER electrocatalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O), ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O), ammonium fluoride (NH4F), urea (CO(NH2)2), and absolute ethanol (C2H5OH) were purchased from Guangdong (China) Xilong Chemical Co., Ltd. Nafion solution (D-520, 5%), commercial Pt/C (20 wt%), and IrO2 (99.9%) catalyst were bought from Alfa Aesar. Carbon cloth (CC) was supplied by Suzhou (China) Yilongsheng Energy Technology Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used as received without any further purification and pretreatment. All aqueous solutions including electrolytes and solutions during sample preparation were prepared with deionized pure water (>18.2 MΩ cm). Before every synthesis, the 2 cm × 4 cm carbon cloth was treated with concentrated HNO3 at 100 °C for 8 h, and then ultrasonically washed with deionized water and ethanol for 30 min, respectively. 2.2 Preparation of pre-catalysts Synthesis of CoMoO4/Co3O4 microflower arrays on carbon cloth (CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC). In a typical synthesis, 1.5 mmol of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.071 mmol of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (the molar ratio of Mo to Co is close to 1:3), 3 mmol of NH4F, and 5 mmol of CO(NH2)2 were dissolved in 36 mL of deionized water, and then vigorously stirred at room temperature for 20 min to form a homogeneous solution. The above solution and the treated carbon cloth were then transferred into a 50 mL Telon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and sealed to heat at 120 °C for 12 h. After the reaction, the carbon cloth was taken out and washed with deionized water, and dried in air at 60 °C. Finally, the dried products were placed in a tube furnace and calcined at 350 °C for 2 h with a heating rate of 2 °C min−1 under an air atmosphere to produce crystalline CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. The electrode size is kept at approximately 1 cm2 for each chronoamperometry activation and electrochemical OER measurement, with a corresponding catalyst loading of about 3.3 mg cm−2. Synthesis of Co 3 O 4 nanosheet arrays on carbon cloth (Co 3 O 4 @CC). For comparison, the whole synthesis process is similar to that of Co3O4/CoMoO4@CC, except without the addition of 0.071 mmol of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O. Synthesis of CoMoO 4 microflower arrays on carbon cloth (CoMoO 4 @CC). Typically, 0.5 mmol Co(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 30 mL deionized water, and the solution was then stirred at room temperature for 10 min by a magnetic stirrer. After 0.071 mmol of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (the molar ratio of Co to Mo is 1:1) and 1 mmol of urea were added to the above solution, the mixture was stirred for 30 min to form a solution. Then, the solution and the treated carbon cloth were transferred to a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 12 h. Finally, the dried products were placed in a quartz tube and calcined at 350 °C for 2 h in a tube furnace. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of pre-catalysts The synthetic procedure of the CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC nanoflower arrays via a two-step method is illustrated in Fig. 1 (a), where commercial carbon cloth (CC) is used as the conductive support due to its high surface area, good electrical conductivity, and low cost. A hydrothermal method was applied firstly to synthesize the Co-Mo precursor on CC and then the obtained precursor was calcined in the air to obtain CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC microflower arrays as the pre-catalyst. The subsequent electrochemical activation triggers a fast phase transformation of CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC due to the leaching of Mo element, leading to the in-situ formation of amorphous CoOOH nanoplates on the Co3O4 nanosheets and thus the formation of an amorphous-crystalline heterostructure (CoOOH/Co3O4) in final R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC catalyst (where “R” denotes the catalyst after reconstruction). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of CoMoO4/Co3O4 powders (Fig. 1b and Fig. S1) scraped down from CC show distinct peaks that can be well indexed to the Co3O4 (JCPDS No.74-2120) and β-CoMoO4 (JCPDS No.21-0868) phases, confirming the successful preparation of hybrid CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. Furthermore, Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 1c) demonstrates the presence of characteristic vibrational modes associated with Co–O vibrations ( F 2 1 g and A 1 1 g ) in Co3O4, as well as Co–O–Mo vibration, O–Mo–O moiety, and Mo=O vibration in β-CoMoO4 [35]. From the field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) (Fig. 1d and Fig. S2) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images (Fig. 1e), it can be seen that CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC exhibits relatively uniform microflowers, each of which is composed of numerous ultrathin nanosheets (Fig. 1f), curved, corrugated, and interconnected to form a three-dimensional (3D) network structure. Subsequent high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image displays the heterostructure between Co3O4 and CoMoO4 in CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC (Fig. 1g), where three diverse lattice fringes with interplanar spacings of 0.24, 0.31, and 0.15 nm are assigned to the (311) of Co3O4, (310) and (024) facets of β-CoMoO4, respectively, which is also confirmed by the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Fig. 1h). Besides, the high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopic (HAADF-STEM) image and corresponding energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mappings (Fig. 1i) reveal the uniform distribution of Mo, Co, and O elements in CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC, with an atom ratio of approximately 1: 3: 7 (Fig. S3). As control samples, Co3O4@CC and CoMoO4@CC samples were prepared by similar synthesis steps to CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. In brief, Co3O4@CC exhibits nanosheet arrays (Figs. S4 and S5), while CoMoO4@CC (Figs. S6 and S7) shows microflower arrays assembled by ultrathin nanosheets with granular textures, which are radically different from that of CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. To investigate the chemical composition and valence state of the as-synthesized materials, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed in detail. The XPS survey spectrum confirms the existence of Mo, Co, and O elements in CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC (Fig. S8). In the high-resolution Mo 3d XPS spectrum (Fig. 1j), for CoMoO4@CC, two main peaks at 231.5 and 234.6 eV can be indexed to the characteristic peaks of Mo6+ of CoMoO4, while for CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC, the binding energies of Mo6+ species exhibit an obvious positive shift of ∼0.38 eV, indicating the decrease of electrons around Mo atoms in CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. This demonstrates the electron transfer from CoMoO4 to Co3O4 due to the close contact of these two components. As for the Co 2p spectrum of CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC (Fig. 1k), the peaks with binding energies at 780.3, 781.8, 795.3, and 796.9 eV are attributed to the Co3+ 2p 3/2, Co2+ 2p 3/2, Co3+ 2p 1/2, and Co2+ 2p 1/2 species, respectively, accompanied with two broad satellite peaks (denoted as “Sat.”) at higher binding energies. The Co 2p spectra for Co3O4@CC and CoMoO4@CC were also analyzed in Fig. 1(k). It is worth noting that the binding energies of Co 2p in CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC are higher than that in CoMoO4@CC but lower than that in Co3O4@CC, indicating the electron transfer between CoMoO4 and Co3O4, which is consistent with the result in the Mo 3d XPS spectra. In the case of O 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 1l), the peaks at 530.3, 531.3, and 532.5 eV for CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC are assigned to the lattice oxygen (OL), oxygen vacancy (OV), and adsorbed water (OW), respectively. Interestingly, the OV peak is also detected in Co3O4@CC but not in CoMoO4@CC, which suggests that the generation of oxygen vacancies comes from the contribution of Co3O4 (Fig. S9 and Note S1). Based on TEM and XPS analyses, the design of the CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC pre-catalyst promotes to in-situ form a highly active heterojunction during the structural reconstruction caused by Mo etching. 3.2 In-situ Raman spectroscopy for monitoring the reconstruction process The electrochemical activation of the pre-catalysts was performed by the chronoamperometry (CA) test in alkaline electrolytes. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), an obvious increase in current density can be observed for CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC and CoMoO4@CC, indicating the occurrence of surface reconstruction and increased electrocatalytic activity. Among them, CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC exhibits a higher magnitude of activity increase. However, for Co3O4@CC, the increased trend of current density cannot be found. The increased OER activity can also be clearly observed from the linear sweep voltammogram (LSV) polarization curves after activation (Fig. S10). However, the OER activity of Co3O4@CC remains unchanged. To gain insight into the reconstruction process, time-dependent in-situ Raman spectra were performed to monitor the structural evolution of the pre-catalysts during the CA test. During the first 5 min test, it can be seen from Fig. 2(b) that three groups of Raman characteristics, such as Co–O–Mo, O–Mo–O, and Mo=O bands, completely disappear in the spectrum of CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC, suggesting the rapid structural evolution of CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC accompanied by the leaching out of Mo species. In particular, two well-defined Raman peaks appearing at ∼463.2 and ∼523.5 cm−1 can be ascribed to the Eg bending vibration and A1g stretching vibration of Co–O [41] respectively, indicating the formation of CoOOH. It has been widely reported that in-situ generated CoOOH is identified as the real active species for OER [42]. To intuitively know the formation of CoOOH, the area of these two Raman peaks over time was fitted, as shown in Fig. 2(c). Clearly, the area of these two peaks increases significantly with time and stabilizes after ∼20 min, suggesting a fast phase reconstruction. Similar structural changes also take place in CoMoO4@CC (Fig. 2d), where the formation of CoOOH together with the disappearance of Mo species can be observed. The leaching of the electrode into the electrolyte over time during the CA test was monitored by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). It can be seen that the Mo species in both CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC and CoMoO4@CC leach out quickly within 20 min and remain stable in the subsequent time (Fig. S11a), while the leaching of Co species in these two catalysts is almost negligible within 60 min (Fig. S11b). After 60 min of testing, the CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC electrode was rinsed with fresh electrolyte to clean the surface and then tested again in the same way in the fresh electrolyte. It is found from Fig. S12 that the amount of Mo species in the fresh electrolyte is absent, demonstrating the complete leaching of Mo species in the previous test, which is also confirmed by the unchanged OER activity in the fresh electrolyte after the CA with 20 min. To determine the existing form of the leached Mo species and its changing rule with the electrolysis time, time-dependent in-situ ultraviolet-visible (UV-Vis) absorption spectroscopy was performed. As presented in Figs. S13 and S14, both CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC and CoMoO4@CC show a distinct absorption peak at about 224 nm at the beginning of the reaction in the electrolyte, which can be assigned to the characteristic peak of MoO4 2− [43], indicating that the Mo species in both electrodes leaches in the form of MoO4 2−. This peak gets stronger gradually with time and stabilizes after ∼20 min, in good agreement with ICP-MS results. The above results strongly reveal the in-situ conversion of the CoMoO4 component into a new CoOOH phase during the reconstruction process. In addition, two important Raman peaks, ascribed to F 2 1 g and A 1 1 g modes of the Co–O vibration of Co3O4, are also noticed in the CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. According to the literature [30], the A 1 1 g and F 2 1 g modes from symmetrical vibration of octahedral cobalt ([CoO6]) and tetrahedral cobalt ([CoO4]) are often used to monitor the evolution process of trivalent [CoO6] and divalent [CoO4] of Co3O4 during the OER process. The area ratio between the F 2 1 g and A 1 1 g peaks ( F 2 1 g / A 1 1 g ) can work as an indicator to evaluate the structural evolution level of Co3O4 during OER. It is clearly observed that for CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC, the F 2 1 g / A 1 1 g value shows no obvious fluctuations over time (Fig. 2c). This is probably because of the similar *OH adsorption capacity of the Cooct and Cotet sites of Co3O4 [30], leading to rapid deprotonation without intermediates accumulation and high OER completeness during the OER process, thus resulting in an imperceptible surface behavior. As a result, the F 2 1 g and A 1 1 g peaks remain firmly present throughout the CA test, implying a dynamically robust Co3O4 phase in the CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. For Co3O4@CC, the peak areas of the E2g and F 2 2 g as well as the F 2 1 g / A 1 1 g value also exhibits no obvious changes with time (Fig. 2e and f), without observing the characteristic peaks belonging to CoOOH. Together with the above all results, it is suggested that CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC underwent a rapid phase reconstruction to form a new CoOOH species and meanwhile maintain a dynamically stable Co3O4 phase (Fig. 2g). This will facilitate the in-situ formation of amorphous-crystalline heterostructures, as described below. 3.3 Characterizations of dynamic amorphous-crystalline heterostructures The morphology and structure of the reconstructed catalysts were investigated. The XRD pattern (Fig. S15) of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC maintains the crystalline Co3O4 phase, which is also reflected in the XRD pattern of R-Co3O4@CC (Fig. S16a), whereas R-CoMoO4@CC shows amorphous features (Fig. S17a), which is result of the generated CoOOH. FESEM images (Fig. 3 a and Fig. S18) demonstrate that the nanosheet morphology is still present in the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC, but the nanosheet structure becomes more open due to the leaching of Mo. More importantly, some new protrusions assembled by small nanoplates can be observed on the nanosheets (Fig. 3b). This unique morphology benefits from the low surface energy on top of the nanosheet skeleton that provides nucleation sites for in-situ formed protrusions. From the TEM images (Fig. 3c and d), the coexistence of nanosheets and nanoplates can be further confirmed, and they are in close contact to form the CoOOH/Co3O4 heterostructure. HRTEM images, corresponding fast Fourier transform (FFT), and the SAED pattern (Fig. 3e–g and Fig. S19) reveal that the heterostructure is composed of amorphous CoOOH nanoplates and crystalline Co3O4 nanosheets. For R-Co3O4@CC, it still exhibits stable nanosheet arrays (Fig. S16b) and a crystalline Co3O4 phase with intact lattice fringes (Fig. S16c and d), while the nanoplate-assembled protrusions are also found in the R-CoMoO4@CC (Fig. S17b and c) and show an amorphous nature (Fig. S17d–f). To further corroborate the complete transformation of CoMoO4 to CoOOH under OER conditions and reveal the local atomic structure of R-CoMoO4@CC, we performed X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra, and the CoOOH reference was used as a comparison. As shown in Fig. S20(a), the position of the absorption edge of the Co K-edge in the R-CoMoO4@CC catalyst almost coincides with that of the Co K-edge in the CoOOH reference, which suggests that the Co state of R-CoMoO4@CC is similar to that of the CoOOH reference. Moreover, the coordination environment of Co atoms in R-CoMoO4@CC was further investigated by the Co K-edge EXAFS spectrum, as revealed in Fig. S20(b). It presents that these two major peaks appearing at 1.50 and 2.58 Å are assigned to the Co–O bond and the radial distance of the Co atom to its neighboring Co atom (Co–Co), respectively. The positions of these two peaks in the R-CoMoO4@CC are consistent with those in the CoOOH reference, demonstrating the generation of CoOOH in R-CoMoO4@CC, which agrees with previous results. Note that the difference in peak intensity between R-CoMoO4@CC and CoOOH reference is due to the presence of oxygen vacancies in the in-situ generated CoOOH in R-CoMoO4@CC. From the above results, it can be inferred that R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC inherited the Co3O4 nanosheets and meanwhile small CoOOH nanoplates were in-situ grown on the nanosheets. Besides, the Mo element is almost completely leached out after reconstruction (Fig. 3h), as revealed by the HAADF-STEM and corresponding EDS element mappings. The chemical composition and valence state changes of the reconstructed catalysts were examined by XPS. In the Mo 3d spectra (Fig. 3i), no Mo signal is detected in R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC and R-CoMoO4@CC, suggesting the Mo leaching during the reconstruction process, which is consistent with the previous analysis. As for the Co 2p spectra (Fig. 3j), three pairs of typical peaks (Co3+, Co2+, and Sat.) are observed in R-CoMoO4@CC, R-Co3O4@CC, and CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. The ratio of Co3+ to Co2+ (Co3+/Co2+) before and after the reconstruction of each catalyst was compared and summarized in Table S1. After the reconstruction, the ratio of Co3+/Co2+ in R-CoMoO4@CC (1.90) and R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC (1.75) is enhanced, which is the result of the generated CoOOH; it is essentially unchanged in R-Co3O4@CC (1.62), consistent with in-situ Raman results. From the binding energy differences of the Co 2p spectra for three catalysts, it can be inferred that a strong electron coupling effect will occur once the Co3O4/CoOOH heterostructure interface is formed. In the O 1s spectra (Fig. S21), a typical peak attributed to the hydroxide bond (OOH) in CoOOH is detected in R-CoMoO4@CC and R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. Notably, the VO peaks in R-CoMoO4@CC and R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC become stronger than those in their pure counterparts, which is the result of the generated amorphous CoOOH. The changes in the content of various oxygen types before and after reconstruction were also compared and summarized in Table S2. Furthermore, R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC shows a stronger EPR signal at g = 2.002 compared with that before reconstruction (Fig. 3k), which is attributed to the in-situ formation of amorphous CoOOH with rich defect structures. The strong coupling effect in the heterojunction and the abundance of oxygen vacancies are expected to enhance OER activity. 3.4 Electrocatalytic OER performance The electrocatalytic OER performance of the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC catalyst was evaluated with a three-electrode system in 1 M KOH electrolyte. For comparison, the OER performance of the R-Co3O4@CC, R-CoMoO4@CC, and commercial IrO2@CC was also tested in the same conditions. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), R-CoMoO4@CC exhibits better OER activity than R-Co3O4@CC, because Mo etching guides the reconstruction process of CoMoO4@CC in a favorable direction, where the in-situ generation of amorphous CoOOH can improve the catalytic activity due to high-valence active Co sites and abundant oxygen vacancies. When the in-situ generation of amorphous CoOOH was also found in R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC, it exhibited the best OER activity among all catalysts with the overpotentials of 250, 305, and 330 mV at the current densities of 10, 50, and 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. 4b), respectively. This excellent OER activity for R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC can be attributed to the synergistic effects between amorphous CoOOH and crystalline Co3O4 in the heterojunction. Considering the contribution of the formed CoOOH to catalytic activity, we controlled the amount of CoOOH by adjusting the molar ratio of Co to Mo to investigate its effect on the catalytic activity, as shown in Fig. S22. The OER activity of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC increases with the increase of the ratio and then remains unchanged at the ratio of 3:1. In addition, we also ruled out the influence of dissolved molybdate ions (MoO4 2−, Fig. S23) in the electrolyte on the catalytic activity of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. To assess the electrocatalytic kinetics of OER, Tafel plots of the catalysts were obtained from the polarization curves. In Fig. 4(c), R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC exhibits the lowest Tafel slope value of 60.5 mV dec−1 compared to R-Co3O4@CC (94.9 mV dec−1), R-CoMoO4@CC (90.6 mV dec−1), commercial IrO2@CC (63.1 mV dec−1), and Bare CC (102.8 mV dec−1). The small Tafel slope value implies that the CoOOH/Co3O4 heterojunction interface effectively accelerates the OER kinetics of the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC catalyst. Most significantly, the obtained OER performance of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC is better than most of the state-of-the-art amorphous and crystalline electrocatalysts in alkaline conditions (Fig. 4d and Table S3). To explore the intrinsic catalytic activity of catalysts, the electrochemical active surface areas (ECSA) were determined by the electrochemical double-layer capacitance (C dl) method (Fig. S24). It is worth noting that the contribution of the support (carbon cloth) may cause the ECSA value of the catalyst to be artificially high, so the powder scraped from the carbon cloth was used for testing. As shown in Fig. 4(e), the C dl value of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4 (8.30 mF cm−2) is higher than that of R-CoMoO4 (6.02 mF cm−2) and R-Co3O4 (4.89 mF cm−2). This largest ECSA for R-CoMoO4/Co3O4 can accelerate the adsorption of reactants at the electrode/electrolyte interface, as revealed by the calculation results later. To compare the intrinsic activity, the normalized OER current densities with ECSA were plotted in Fig. S25. Obviously, R-CoMoO4/Co3O4 displays a higher intrinsic activity with j ECSA = 0.25 mA cm−2 at 1.55 V, which is about 2 and 3 times as high as that of R-CoMoO4 (0.12 mA cm−2) and R-Co3O4 (0.08 mA cm−2), respectively, indicating that the increase of ECSA can expose more intrinsically active sites for OER. Meanwhile, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed further to elucidate the electrode kinetics under OER operating conditions, and the corresponding EIS plots were subsequently fitted with an equivalent circuit diagram to extract the relevant physical parameters. In Fig. 4(f), the appearance of a depressed semicircle in the high-frequency region indicates a charge-transfer process during the OER. The R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC electrode exhibits low charge-transfer resistance (R ct) of 10.6 Ω at the electrolyte-electrode interface compared to R-CoMoO4@CC (30.5 Ω) and R-Co3O4@CC (14.1 Ω), suggesting a more favorable OER kinetics and efficient mass transportation on the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. The electrochemical stability of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC was first evaluated by the cyclic voltammetry (CV) cycling test in 1 M KOH. As presented in Fig. 4(g), R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC shows excellent durability, as the polarization curves before and after 5000 cycles almost overlapped. Moreover, the long-term chronopotentiometry curves at 10 and 50 mA cm−2 (Fig. 4h) clearly demonstrate that the working potentials can remain stable for 200 h of continuous electrolysis without obvious degradation. In addition, its good stability is also reflected in R-Co3O4@CC (Fig. S26), which benefits from the high thermodynamic stability of Co3O4. While for R-CoMoO4@CC, the working potential at 50 mA cm−2 can only remain highly stable for 30 h of continuous electrolysis, and decay in the subsequent electrolysis. The reason for the decay is the formed amorphous surface in R-CoMoO4@CC collapsing and dissolving into the electrolyte [36]. Thus, under the interaction of the amorphous CoOOH and the crystallized Co3O4 substrate, R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC exhibits excellent stability. The morphology and structure of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC after the stability test were also characterized. As shown in Fig. S27(a), the XRD pattern of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC after testing maintains the crystalline Co3O4 phase. Moreover, the F 2 1 g and A 1 1 g modes of Co–O in Co3O4 and the Eg and A1g modes of Co–O in CoOOH exist stably in the Raman spectrum (Fig. S27b) of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. The FESEM image shown in Fig. S28 still displays the morphologies consisting of crystalline Co3O4 nanosheets and amorphous CoOOH nanoplates. These results demonstrate the excellent stability of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC after the test. 3.5 DFT calculations and OER mechanisms As for the improvement of OER activity via the surface reconstruction caused by the removal of Mo, we first discussed in detail the effect of Mo on the enhancement of catalytic activity both experimentally and theoretically. The CV method was utilized to investigate the effect of Mo leaching in CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC on the adsorption of reactants (OH−). As shown in Fig. S29(a), CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC shows a peak at ∼0.845 V, corresponding to the formation of *OH (OH− + * → *OH + e−) [44,45], but this peak gets stronger for R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC without Mo. This result indicates the enhanced adsorption of OH− reactants on R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC after Mo leaching, which can be attributed to that the in-situ generated CoOOH improves the adsorption of OH−reactants on R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC [41,46]. Furthermore, the adsorption energies of OH− reactants on Mo-containing and Mo-free catalysts through density functional theory (DFT) were compared. When using the Co atom as the active site, the adsorption energy of OH− on R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC is calculated to be 0.37 eV (Fig. S29b), which is significantly lower than that on CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC (0.70 eV). Therefore, these theoretical and experimental results strongly reveal that the leaching of Mo causes an improvement in the adsorption energy of OH−, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity. DFT calculations were performed to gain further insight into the origin of the high OER performance of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. Based on experimental results, the slab model of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC includes the energetically favorable Co3O4 (111) surface and the amorphous CoOOH surface determined by molecular dynamics calculations. The optimized configurations of R-Co3O4@CC, R-CoMoO4@CC, and R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC models are shown in Figs. S30–S32. The electronic structure of the models was investigated by calculating the Bader charge and charge density difference. The calculated Bader charge (Table S4) shows that the charge of CoOOH decreases and the charge of Co3O4 increases after the formation of the heterojunction for R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC, indicating the charge transfer from CoOOH to Co3O4, which matches well with the XPS results. Moreover, the calculated charge density difference (Fig. 5 a) result further demonstrates that electrons are depleted on CoOOH (blue area) while electrons are accumulated (yellow area) on Co3O4, meaning a strong electronic coupling effect between amorphous CoOOH and crystallized Co3O4 for R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. To further understand the electronic structure, the density of states (DOS) was calculated. The results in Fig. 5(b) show that the charge density of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC near the Fermi level is greater than that of R-CoMoO4@CC, indicating enhanced electron mobility. Moreover, the DOS at the Fermi level for R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC mainly comes from the spin-down electrons of Co due to the small spin-up part of Co and electron density of O, which is also reflected in R-CoMoO4@CC. This demonstrates that Co atoms are the main catalytic active sites, especially those from CoOOH providing abundant active sites for R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC, thereby promoting OER activity. Furthermore, the DOS of Co 3d orbitals analysis (Fig. 5c) shows that the d-band center of Co sites in R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC (−1.539 eV) is much closer to the Fermi level than that of R-CoMoO4@CC (−1.803 eV) and R-Co3O4@CC (−2.309 eV), suggesting an enhanced bonding with the OER intermediates. It has been well-accepted that the OER process in alkaline media involves four reaction steps, including step 1. OH− + * → *OH + e−; step 2. *OH + OH− → O* + H2O + e−; step 3. O*+OH− → *OOH + e−; and step 4. *OOH + OH− → O2 + H2O + e− + * [47–50]. The Gibbs free energy diagrams of *OH, *O, and *OOH adsorbed on the surface of R-Co3O4@CC, R-CoMoO4@CC, and R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC were shown in Fig. 5(d and e). It shows that under U = 0 V, the rate-determining step (RDS) with the largest energy barrier is the conversion of O* to *OOH intermediate for the three catalysts. As for R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC, the energy barrier of RDS is calculated to be 1.80 eV, which is lower than that of R-CoMoO4@CC (1.93 eV) and R-Co3O4@CC (2.09 eV). At U = 1.23 V, the different energetic trends become obvious. The heterojunction in R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC reduces the initial energy barrier (−0.86 eV) for *OH formation, which is nearly 2 times lower than that in R-CoMoO4@CC (−0.49 eV) and R-Co3O4@CC (−0.40 eV). It means that *OH is easily adsorbed on the surface of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. Furthermore, the stable O* formation from the system of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC determines the formation of *OOH with an energy barrier of 0.57 eV, corresponding to a 0.57 V theoretical overpotential, which is lower than that of R-CoMoO4@CC (0.70 V) and R-Co3O4@CC (0.86 V), in good agreement with the experimental trend. The optimal reaction pathway and corresponding structural configurations for R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC are shown in Fig. 5(f), and other catalysts are presented in Figs. S33 and S34. Thus, the heterostructure in R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC can regulate the electronic structure of Co sites and optimize the adsorption energies of the *OH intermediate on Co sites, leading to enhanced catalytic activity. Based on the above discussions, the enhanced OER performance of the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC catalyst can be attributed to two major factors (Fig. 5g). (1) The in-situ formed amorphous CoOOH provides a large number of active sites and abundant defects, while the crystalline Co3O4 with high structural stability strengthens the conductivity and accelerates the charge transport. (2) The heterojunction between CoOOH and Co3O4 components with synergistic effects modulates the d-band center of Co sites and optimizes the adsorption of oxygen intermediates on Co sites, achieving excellent activity and stability for OER. 3.6 Applications in electrolytic water splitting and zinc-air batteries For its superior OER performance of the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC catalyst, the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC catalyst was assembled into an H-type water electrolyzer and a home-made zinc-air battery (ZAB) to investigate its practical application. To begin with, an H-type water electrolyzer (Fig. 6 a) with a commercial separating membrane was constructed via using R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC as the anode and Pt/C (20 wt%) loaded on carbon cloth as the cathode in 1.0 M KOH at room temperature. The polarization curves in Fig. 6(b) disclose that the OER activity of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC||Pt/C achieves an overall voltage of 1.51 V at 10 mA cm−2, which is superior to that of the commercial IrO2||Pt/C couple (1.55 V). Fig. 6(c) indicates that the experimentally produced O2 volumes match the theoretical value well, with an average Faraday efficiency of ∼95.42%. Furthermore, the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC||Pt/C couple shows excellent stability, as evidenced by the negligible potential shift of only ∼10 mV at 10 mA cm−2 after 10,000 cycles (Fig. 6d). What is more, upon performing chronopotentiometry measurement at a constant current of 10 mA cm−2, R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC||Pt/C provides stable OER catalysis over 500 h, with an overpotential increase of only ∼50 mV (Fig. 6e), demonstrating its potential for practical electrolytic water applications. Then, a home-made ZAB prototype (Fig. 6f) was assembled, in which a Zn plate worked as the anode and R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC served as the air cathode in 6.0 M KOH electrolyte with 0.2 M Zn(CH3COO)2. For comparison, the battery performance of the commercial IrO2 + Pt/C couple (a mass ratio of 1:1) was also tested. To evaluate the overall efficiency of the as-prepared electrodes, the potential difference (ΔE) between the half-wave potential (E 1/2) for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 (Ej =10) for OER was calculated (ΔE = Ej =10 − E 1/2). As illustrated in Fig. S35, the ΔE for the self-supported R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC catalyst is 0.57 V in 6 M KOH, which is much comparable to that of the commercial IrO2 + Pt/C couple (0.58 V), suggesting its outstanding bifunctional activity in alkaline medium [51,52]. In practice, the ZAB driven by the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC catalyst affords an open-circuit potential of 1.43 V (Fig. 6g) and a maximum power density of 120.3 mW cm−2 (Fig. 6h), which significantly surpasses those of the ZAB driven by IrO2 + Pt/C. The galvanostatic discharge measurements for R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC-based ZAB exhibit a smaller voltage drop at increasing densities ranging from 1 to 50 mA cm−2 compared to that of IrO2 + Pt/C, and the discharge recovers reversibly when the current density gets back to 1 mA cm−2, indicating the distinguished rate performance and superior reversibility of R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC (Fig. S36 and Note S2). Furthermore, the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC-based ZAB exhibits a higher specific capacity of 654 mA h g−1 at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 under the condition of continuous oxygen supply than the IrO2 + Pt/C-based ZAB (572 mA h g−1) (Fig. 6i). Under the condition of no continuous oxygen supply (close to practical application), the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC-based ZAB also exhibits a higher specific capacity than the IrO2 + Pt/C-based ZAB (Fig. S37). The long-term durability of the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC-based ZAB was assessed by continuous galvanostatic discharging/charging cycling tests with charging for 10 min and discharging for 10 min. As shown in Fig. 6(j), the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC-based ZAB affords an ultralong lifespan of over 1200 h at 10 mA cm−2 without any obvious increase of voltage gaps, while the IrO2 + Pt/C-based ZAB showed a significant increase of voltage gaps after only ∼50 h. Thus, the above results strongly demonstrate the promising applications of the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC catalyst in electrocatalytic water splitting and rechargeable ZAB. 4 Conclusions In summary, we successfully developed an efficient electrocatalyst for OER composed of in-situ formed amorphous CoOOH on dynamically stable crystalline Co3O4 nanosheets supported on carbon cloth by the electrochemical activation of a hybrid CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC pre-catalyst. In-situ Raman and multiple ex-situ techniques results reveal the selective phase reconstruction process of CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC and the formation of dynamically stable amorphous-crystalline heterostructures in resultant R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC. Theoretical calculations and experimental results demonstrate that the heterostructures with synergistic effects efficiently modulate the 3d orbitals of Co sites and optimize the adsorption of oxygen-containing intermediates on Co sites, thus facilitating the OER kinetics. As a result, the R-CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC electrode exhibited a low overpotential of 250 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 for OER in 1 M KOH. Impressively, the electrolytic water splitting and zinc-air batteries built with this electrode achieve remarkable performance and ultra-high stability, demonstrating its feasibility for practical applications. This work not only provides a novel perspective for the design of low-cost and efficient OER electrocatalysts with amorphous-crystalline heterostructures, but also encourages promising applications of in-situ constructed amorphous-crystalline heterostructures in sustainable energy systems. coredata.dc:description: Surface reconstruction yields real active species in electrochemical oxygen evolution reaction (OER) conditions; however, rationally regulating reconstruction in a targeted manner for constructing highly active OER electrocatalysts remains a formidable challenge. Here, an electrochemical activation strategy with selective etching was utilized to guide the reconstruction process of a hybrid cobalt-molybdenum oxide (CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC) in a favorable direction to improve the OER performance. Both in-situ Raman and multiple ex-situ characterization tools demonstrate that controlled surface reconstruction can be easily achieved through Mo etching, with the formation of a dynamically stable amorphous-crystalline heterostructure. Theoretical calculations together with experimental results reveal that the synergistic effects between amorphous CoOOH and crystalline Co3O4 are crucial in enhancing the catalytic performance. Consequently, the reconstructed CoMoO4/Co3O4@CC exhibits a low overpotential of 250 mV to achieve a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH, and more importantly it can be practiced in electrolytic water splitting and rechargeable zinc-air batteries devices, achieving ultra-long stability for over 500 and 1200 h, respectively. This work provides a promising route for the construction of high-performance electrocatalysts.
